description:
Chinese friend introduced me to this place and I'm obsessed.

1. The boiled spicy fish is super delicious - 5 stars - I've had it 3 times this week already.  Fish is super fresh, the flavors just delightful and frankly absolutely addicting!  

2. Spicy string beans - 4 stars

Added bonus, the phenomenal flavors without MSG and health score of 98 out of 100!  Enough said.
author: Lev E.

description:
Bland and boring.

In a pinch, it might do, but we tried the other night a few things and they were just bland and not that good. 

Loads better Chinese food in the city. Try one of those.
author: Jason H.

description:
Another Szechuan restaurant opened in the China town... and most of the employees are Cantonese. I believe the cooks are also Cantonese that's why they make the classic Szechuan dish nowhere like a Szechuan dish. 
We ordered Shredded pork /w garlic sauce (鱼香肉丝) and Beef boiled /w flaming chilli oil (水煮牛肉).
The shredded pork is a classic Szechuan dish and it's very easy to tell if it's authentic or Americanized or else. First, the pork was off-taste due to bad preservation; second, the flavor was too sweet and even worse than the Americanized version. I would give it 1 star.
The boiled beef was decent. The flavor was good and tasted like what I had in China. The beef was a bit too chewy. I would give it 4 stars.
So on average, the food ranges from 2 to 3 stars. But the service was also bad, every time, we needed to wave to the server several times to raise her attention, although we were the only customers in the restaurant.
author: Zhongjie W.

description:
if you are looking for real Chinese food, you can leave now, it is designed for American only, don't be fooled by its name.

Giving one star is coz the waiter told me it is traditional Chinese food, but really not.
author: Peter L.

description:
Part two of my weekly office lunch. Our delivery order from Little Szechuan arrived via Caviar on Friday, June 8th a little after 12:15pm.

*Shanghai Steamed Dumplings: 6 ($7.98)
*Five Spices Beef Roll: Spicy ($9.98)
*Chicken Lunch Specials: General Tso's Chicken, Brown Rice ($9.98)

I got the XLBs as I adore a good soup dumpling. These were meaty, but not very soupy. Also, the sauce didn't have any ginger which I missed. I still made it work with some green onions and hot sauce I had at work. I tried the beef pancake and it was okay. My coworker liked the hoisin sauce in it as it was reminiscent of a peking duck bun. I didn't try the lunch special, but I think it was enjoyed by all. It did come with fried rice instead of brown rice, but I don't think anyone minded though.

Decent spot for Chinese food. I think there are better spots out there, but overall, the dishes weren't too bad.
author: Elena N.

description: I cannot live my life without spicy food of a great variety of kinds. I don't have to eat fancy everyday but I need to be fed properly. Moral of the restaurant : it's my #1 ubereats most frequently ordered restaurant and I ordered literally all their spicy food to fulfill my mundane life on a daily basis. Non - sichuanese diners might find it hard to understand my feelings , but for real , it fed me well and I am grateful for this.
author: Lulu Y.

description: It was pretty bland.  For a szechuan place, there should definitely be more pop in the food.  Both the spicy beef and intestine dish and the mapo tofu were pretty boring.  Too much oil.  Not enough heat.
author: Mike F.

description:
Ordered takeout to my hotel.
Delivery: on expected time (1hr to Union Square), he came to my room. 
Packaging: nice, tidy, food was still warm.
Food: I love Chinese dumplings and wontons. Ordered spicy wonton, wonton soup, and chicken-mushroom dumplings. For me the meat in the wontons was too "dense"-stiff/hard not juicy and had a little of a weird sidetaste. The soup broth was just ok, but nice veggies and shrimp, and chicken cubes that were tasteless. The chicken dumplings were kinda tasteless too and just meaty in the bad way.
Result: the meat quality was a dissapointment. I didn't finish my dinner. Otherwise everything was smooth and pretty tasty.
author: Hanna M.

description: I believe this is the one of the best Szechuan restaurant in SF. It's hard to describe if they have something special that other place don't. But the classic Szechuan dishes are just great here.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
TBH, this is a serious gem in the middle of a SUPER touristy area. Used to come here to grab quick lunches when I worked nearby - which isn't an option for me from the financial district anymore. 

BUT I took the fam here a while back (while thinking of a big spot to fit a group of 12 on the fly), and they're just as obsessed w this spot as I am now! Took the fam here again yesterday, and boy are we trouble. Some of us don't eat meat (me), soy or nuts (cousin's deathly allergic), spicy (aunt), etc etc. Most places would've rolled their eyes and said, seriously? But not here! We had lists of special requests (hate being those ppl, but we had to be in this case), and the staff here were amazing about it. Shout out to their amazingly patient and accommodating staff! 

My fav dishes here are: salt and pepper fish (perfectly crispy and slightly spicy), boiled fish in spicy oil (SO good), pea sprout veggies (has just the right bite to it), and hot and sour soup (spicy to vinegar ratio is on point). ALSO, yest we tried their honey walnut calamari...never had this anywhere before, but it was super delicious! We even asked for the walnuts on the side bc of my cousin, and they said no problemo. Woot woot. 

To conclude, I'm a fan. The staff is great. The food is really delicious. You should come here. 5 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
If you are anything like me and get intimidated by super long menus, do yourself a favor follow my advice... 

You MUST get the Spicy Noodle Beef Soup, it is the best I've ever had in my life! The noddles are thicker and fluffy and soak in the beef broth in an amazing way. It's got a little bit of heat and a vinegar aftertaste that I really, really enjoy. It's such a huge bowl I can't finish the soup in one sitting. Excellent value for the price. 

The staff is extremely polite and the restaurant is clean and inviting.
author: Kat L.

description:
I hike almost a mile from my FiDi office for Little Szechuan's amazing lunch deal:

$10 for soup, salad, a flavored iced tea and an entree with either rice or fried rice.  My go-to is the Kung Pao fish, for a generous serving of spicy, tender filleted fish, tossed with bell peppers, zucchini, peanuts and of course, chili peppers.

The restaurant is spacious, clean, and the service is quick and attentive.  I almost don't want to post this review because there's never a wait, probably because this is a hidden gem that FiDi crowds have not yet discovered.
author: Audacity L.

description: Honey walnut chicken was put together poorly! Very disappointed! I was not expecting it to be chunky, and super sweet. I paid about $13 for this as well and am not happy about the order. Picture shows what they handed to me. Does not look tasty at all.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Hands down the fanciest packaging in a take-out order ever, especially when it came to pot stickers and soup dumplings. They don't just toss them in a carton and let them roll about and get all messed up in the delivery process. With care, they put them in these nice reusable containers, custard tins to maintain shape, and present overall, very well. 

Food is hot, tasty, fresh, and made with good quality ingredients. Definitely vegetarian friendly as well. Will keep this at the top of my list for delivery or party orders in the near future. 

Reasonable pricing for pot stickers, both meat and veg ($7.98), soup dumplings (6 for $7.98!!) , egg rolls (3 for $4.98), and crab rangoons (6 for $7.98). 

Great for party appetizers, small bites for a team shindig, or family-style meal sharing. I would feel comfortable using this business to cater a happy hour party since their delivery timeliness and presentation was so great. 

Free delivery on Eat24 with $35 or more, and with an order that large, you also get a free side of pot stickers (a deal of $7.98) so it's a good option for a group/party order. Be sure to follow-up with Eat24 and/or the restaurant direct if you order for an advanced date, so they do not confuse a future order date with the date you placed the order (this occurred and the delivery person did not speak English so I could not explain the situation mix-up on their end, and the food was just dumped our lobby). They did accommodate by re-delivering on the correct date free of charge. Superb!
author: Alison A.

description:
We came here for dinner on New Year's Eve. Great place for family union or friend bonding. Not crowded at all! Also staff here were really friendly. 

Sometimes they have Lady M in stock. Just ask!

We ordered roast fish (烤鱼) and cumin lamb (孜然羊肉). They only had cat fish at that time, but still the dish was delicious. Overall recommended!
author: Yu S.

description:
This place just screams tourist trap in SF Chinatown, but if you walk inside, you will definitely find your fair share of Chinese diners. The interesting part is that the staff do not speak Cantonese but speak Mandarin, which is unusual for SF Chinatown, but it is Szechuan food so that more than makes sense. Not that that has any bearing on the restaurant, but I suppose that means they know how to make Szechuan food.
Anyway, the decor is really well done and the inside looks like new. We were seated right away but when we tried to ask in Cantonese about the lunch special that was advertised outside, they said to wait one minute and then never came back to our table. A Mandarin speaking family was seated well after us who had their orders taken well before us and served drinks. I was angered by this and ready to get up, but my boyfriend insisted that we sit down. After what must have been 20 minutes after the Mandarin family was served, a waitress came over and tried to take our order in English. We told her we wanted the lunch special menu and so, she had to give it to us and leave yet again to let us look at the menu. Btw, this menu isn't actually handed out during the weekends unless you ask. So many points off for this experience already. The restaurant wasn't even busy, but I did see someone waiting for a takeout order get frustrated by the wait to order and pick up the food.
When we finally ordered, the food came out in a timely manner. I got the mapo tofu, my favorite Szechuan dish that I've even enjoyed in Beijing (with some...pain). The mapo tofu here lacked the spice I was looking for though. I enjoyed it, but it just wasn't spicy enough. My boyfriend enjoyed his meal at least and we had a good time together once we were finally served.
So..I would say this place is good for the food if you order spicy, but the service sucks. Ask for your food to be extra spicy! If you don't like spicy, you are in the wrong restaurant though...
author: Jenn T.

description: Had to stay late for work last week, so we ordered delivery from Little Szechuan. Didn't amaze me but it's what you'd find in an average Szechuan restaurant. Surprisingly that they sell Lady M (thumb up for that).
author: Jack T.

description: I had the lamb in chili oil and it was the best szechuan dish I ever ate. It was the perfect amount of spice and flavor. It took a while to make my order but it seemed like a busy night for them but I'll gladly wait for good tasting food.
author: Dff F.

description:
I just found a hidden amazing Szechuan's restaurant! This place is amazing!!
I ordered braised crispy chicken with red chili oil and Ma Po tofu for dinner. They were the best Szechuan food of my life!! The meat was very crispy and tender at the same time. They are spicy and tasty as well as high quality. 
I would come back more often! Good work chef!
author: Ivy Whywhy W.

description:
Watermelon juice in this restaurant is:
Water +water melon flesh
I'm pissed, give an appropriate explanation
author: Zhang S.

description:
The food here is very tasty. We've ordered delivery twice. 
My order yesterday was this: 

-Braised crispy chicken with red chili oil - good
-Beef chow fun - great
-Twice cooked pork - tasty but disappointed; what few pieces of pork I got were good but I somehow ended up with mostly potatoes and a few slices of pork. see picture.
-Vegetarian hot & sour soup - bland, would not get again
-Free veggie pot stickers via Eat24 - quite flavorful and tasty, though doughy

My husband previously order what I think is cumin lamb and another pork dish that were both excellent. 

There are many photos posted on yelp for this restaurant by the business - it would be good to also see the names of all items so I know what to order.
author: Mellie D.

description: Very tasty! Reasonably priced, if u can get the lunch special. I and my aunt were able to get it thanks to the nice waitress. It usually only available during the weekdays only but wasn't stated on the menu in the front of the restaurant. We ordered the Szechuan eggplant and braised tofu & mushrooms. It came with a drink (peach black tea and Hong Kong style milk tea), a bowl of soup and a small side salad.
author: Larissa L.

description:
Amazing Sichuan food- both for dine in and del very. I've found their food to be among the highest quality and consistency as far as Sichuan food is concerned. Their standouts are the mapo tofu, Tan Tan noodles, imperial fried rice, the crispy chicken, and fish in chili oil. The spiciness is the right amount of mouth numbing quality and the flavors are out of this world.

Also - it's worth noting their restaurant is very nicely updated. Definitely worth a visit when you're in the Broadway area.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Good service, price, and food... but one day we saw something suspicious.
A server took a bowl of rice left by a group of people, took a scoop out from the top, and put the rest in the rice cooker. This made us think that they were reusing rice.
EDIT: the owner replied claiming that I have posted another review elsewhere, in contradiction with this review. This is not the case as such review does not exist.
author: Felipe O.

description:
This used to be my favorite Chinese restaurant in town. I went to have dinner with my husband last Sat and it seems their cook has changed. They gave us half cooked chicken. When I asked the waitress for cooking it more she was like this can't be true because we fry the chicken first.. well it was not well done I said. She took it back to the cook n brought the dish. It was better but still not well done. We finished our dinner and just that night I started having nausea, diarrhea and stomach pain. Next day I woke up with fever n still had that stomach pain. This must be due to the uncooked chicken or the poor hygiene of this restaurant. Everything was fine before that.
Stop serving uncooked food to people n take care of the hygiene of your restaurant.
author: Anu S.

description:
Amanzing tofu soup...amazing chicken in coconut and red chili oil...
The noodles were soft and tasty....
The place was clean and very nice .
The staff was very friendly as well....
A very good Chinese find in broadway
author: Abhilasha S.

description:
Not great. I ordered delivery, which didn't take too long, but I ordered my chicken with black bean sauce spicy and it was the mildest dish I've tasted. To make matters worse, the black bean sauce seemed like whatever default sauce or gravy they had with a few black beans added, but it didn't have the umami or garlic flavors that are present when you get a good version of the sauce. Poor quality chicken. 

The potstickers were passable, but also bland. I wouldn't get them again. For these prices, I expected better.
author: Joanna L.

description: We're from out of town and visited SF and craved for Chinese Szechuan food. Tried Little Szechuan when we visited SF about a month ago. We loved it and came back for more. Our most favorites are fish filet with spicy chef sauce and braised crispy chicken. But the eggplant and twice cooked pork are good too. Their teas are great with the spicy food! Would definitely come back again!
author: CN C.

description: OMG Lady M Green Tea Cake！！！！ Iove itttttt！！！then I order whole spicy fish and braised chicken with a lot chili taste amazing,  service friendly , highly recommend. For sure come back .
author: Yuying L.

description:
I was craving for Szechuan food when I saw this place on Yelp. When I came into the restaurant and after I got seated, the waiters gave us some peanuts as appetizers, which I thought was pretty nice. I scanned the menu and saw the only dish that appealed to me was the Pork Spare Ribs with Sour Pickle Noodle Soup. To be honest, I really only wanted the sour pickle noodle soup but not really pork spare ribs (I was have preferred to see other types of protein on there, otherwise I would've been fine if there was no meat at all). As one of the few places in Chinatown that serves Szechuan food, I was okay with the fact that there were limited options when it came to meat toppings since I primarily came for the sour pickle noodle soup. The fried spare ribs went nicely with the sour pickle noodle soup, but I think the sourness wasn't really emphasized since there were very few pickles in there. The noodles were nice and the broth tasted mellow. I was expecting this dish to be overwhelmingly sour but I think that is a misunderstanding on my part since I thought the sourness was infused into the soup. 

The service was a little slow, but taking into account that I only saw three workers there out in the front, I think this is to be expected. Overall, I think the dish, appetizer, and service was alright and would give this place a 3.
author: Nelson X.

description: I tried Dong Po marinated pork and spicy twice cooked pork. It was very delicious. The meat was deliciously succulent and tenders with a great flavor being updated from meat's fat. The only thing I don't like was the parking. It's was hard to find parking during dinner time. Everything was good except that.
author: Connie H.

description:
Great Szechuan restaurant that hosts large groups! Service was great and the food was all served family style for us.

Every dish we had was delicious. My favorite part of the meal was the beef rolls ($10). I highly recommend them! The peking duck ($23) was also amazing especially with the buns. The black sesame ball dessert was memorable and our entire group loved them.
author: Linda X.

description:
I ordered two dishes for delivery. The delivery guy asked me to come down as he did not find a parking spot which I agreed to. When I called back, he said he left the order at my door.

To my surprise, when I go to my room, the bag was on the floor with both the boxes open and food scrambled in the bag. Maybe he left the bag hanging on the door handle and it slipped.

Chicken chow main with lemon chicken was not a terrible combination. I rather lime my food in separate containers.
author: Sai Teja L.

description:
Very americanized szechuan food. Not very spicy. 

For better americanized chinese food you could go to panda instead. It tasted like someone went to safeway, got the black bean sauce, and just threw it on some meat. The spicy dishes were not very spicy, sauce a watery consistency. 

Had 3 lunch specials and an appetizer: 
Xiao Long Bao appetizer
Szechuan beef
Fish Fillet with Chilli Sauce
Shredded Pork w/ Garlic Sauce. 

Skip this spot. Try spicy king in china town or chong qing xiao mian. 
3 Spices in Oakland is also worth a try.
author: sharon s.

description:
Want authentic Sichuan cuisine that will leave your mouth spiced out and numb? This is your place. I had the spicy boiled beef lunch special, and OH MY GOD. This is my favorite regional dish, and I've had it at a few different places, but this place goes crazy on the Sichuan peppercorns. Probably too many, but I pushed them off to the side and stopped biting into them directly (don't suggest you chew them either).  
A little more upscale than your typical Chinese restaurant. I'm coming back to try other stuff!
author: Nancy O.

description:
We went to Little Schezuan on 31st night in San Francisco china town for a family dinner and we really enjoyed the food.

The restaurant has a pretty good ambience. The service was extremely good considering China town was packed with tourists and locals on a New Year's Eve.

We ordered cumin lamb, prawns fried rice, kungpao tofu, and chicken, sweet and sour veg soup and all the dishes were delicious. 

I would highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Amit S.

description:
What are you doing at this hour on Broadway? I hope your not at one of those girly places next door?! Well, your money will go a long way here compared to those places surrounding this spot. Inside is clean and nicely decorated. There are some red lanterns hanging from the ceiling which give it a bit of visual interest. On an odd or off night this restaurant will not be very full but other than that the ambiance couldn't be more pleasant. Service is great and the employees are friendly. 

The menu is huge - so much selection. Take a few minutes to really soak it all in and ask for help from a server or a friend that frequents the place. Appetizers, cold plates, soup, salad, pork, seafood, poultry, curry, vegetables, beef/lamb, egg foo young, noodles/rice, juice, ice tea, milk tea, smoothies, dessert... Just the different flavors of the ice teas alone are overwhelming. Usually when I see a menu this long I get wondering how any restaurant can pull it off but I guess they are skilled and talented enough to juggle all of that at once.
author: Stefan T.

description: Fun place, spacious, enjoyed the food, an extensive menu with just anything and everything including tea beverages. Feels like a Chinese version of a Hong Kong style contemporary cafe, but that serves beer and wine and tvs that plays sports. Mind you however, it's not like some loungey place, more like a Chinese style practical but spacious bistro with large tables and booths, perhaps like a modern style Chinese spiked up dennys. They cook really quickly, super fast service, love that, and good takeout packaging, and have decent hours (would be great if they close at 1am). Recommended!
author: Juls C.

description:
I watched as a waitress went over to two large party tables to bus them. She grabbed the two large rice bowls from the center of the lazy susans and walked over to a desk. She then took a single scoop of some rice from one of the bowls and threw it in the trash (I'm guessing the rice was discolored by food). She then walked the two bowls over to the rice cooker, opened the cooker, and dumped the rice in. Afterwards she returned to her mobile bussing station near the tables, put the now empty rice bowls on the station, and continued bussing the tables.

When I raised concern to my waitress I was of course told that I was mistaken and none of this had happened. She continued talking for several minutes about how clean they are. She mentioned their health score of 98 which means they would not reuse rice. She also mentioned that the rice bowls are for large groups which means they're clean and nobody would be eating directly from them.
author: Thomas H.

description: Ordered for lunch through postmates and sadly this place missed the mark for me. Maybe because we got take out, but the sesame chicken was drenched in sauce and totally soggy. Not crispy at all. The only thing that saved them was the soup dumplings that were on par with others but I'll pass on this place next time. :(
author: Dana J.

description: I've actually never left a 1-star review on Yelp. But damn this place deserves it. The food is just gross. The fried rice tastes like it was soaked in dirty water and soy sauce for the past 48 hours then flash fried in a pan. It's nasty. The spicy dumplings were cold and had a disgusting aftertaste. The orange chicken was equally as bad. I'd highly suggest avoiding this spot ... we wish we did
author: Scott T.

description: How little Little Szechuan manages to produce the most perfectly mediocre Chinese food I've ever had is a mystery. It's not bad, but it's certainly not good. It just is.
author: Eric A.

description: I really like their BBQ fish, just like the same taste when I visited Szechuan. And their service is excellent. I also got a yummy cake from them on my birthday. It shipped from LA and it's in their secret menu. It has so many layers and taste like heaven. Thanks so much!
author: Xin Z.

description: I forgot I rated 1 star 2 years ago and tried this place again. Ordered spring beans and spicy chili beef t'endors. the spring bean is over cooked, the beef and t'endors have a really weird taste. I throw most of them away and just hope I don't get sick tomorrow.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Pick up / delivery.

Spicy Szechuan Shumai $8.48--large and juicy, however the spicy really just means some sriracha on top.  These are good if you want dim sum but aren't able to actually go to a dim sum restaurant.  I'd get this again.

Spicy wontons $6.98--PASS on these.  There are much better pretty much anywhere else.  The meat was hard and overcooked, and the flavor just wasn't there, even though they were covered in chili oil.

Beef Cubes with Egg Tofu in Honey Sauce $14.98.  Very similar to Crustacean's beef cubes, without the pepper.  Honey sauce is a little too thick and gummy and could use some spiciness.  The egg tofu has a great flan-like texture.  This tofu does not pair very well with the beef (the beef should be with something crispier), but all in all the dish is decent.

The restaurant is huge, though--it has an underground banquet room that you can have a large party in, and the main restaurant seems to be empty (except for a couple tables) even on Friday/Saturday nights.  All in all, you should venture to a more authentic restaurant a couple streets down in Chinatown.
author: Vanessa O.

description: Was afraid to try spicy for lunch because scare to upset the stomach.  However found some mild choices and seem like a good value as well.  $10 get you peanuts, salad, hot and spicy soup , choice of rice, and drink.  Chinatown probably provide a lot of competition.  They even cater to tourist groups. For the distance, choices, and value, this became a regular hangout.
author: Tony C.

description:
Ordered delivery from our Nov Hill hotel, after selecting this restaurant based on Yelp reviews for Chinese restaurants delivering in our area late on a Sunday night. The order arrived lightening-fast, hot and well-packed. 

We ordered: 

- scallion pancakes (savory, flakey, perfectly crisp)

- General Tso chicken (good quality meat, and perfectly crisp - but the tasty sauce was slightly too... gloopy for my taste)

- beef w/broccoli (perfectly cooked broccoli, great light sauce. I wish the beef had s more "seared" taste/appearance as steamed beef isn't very appealing)

- vegetarian hot and sour soup (skip it)

- vegetarian egg rolls (very tasty, fresh, and crisp)

In short, not a bad pick for delivery, but I'm sure there are better options available.
author: Erica A.

description: I like things to be easy. This place is easy. If i can order via yelp, i automatically love them. But if the food was bad, I'd never order again from here.  Let me just say....i crave the dry ribs now...all the way from New York City...it's salty as hell but in the best way possible. It sucks that there's a $20 minimum but honestly, I've walked there from the hotel before and trust me...that $20 minimum is more than justified after walking up THAT hill. Now i bring a lunchbox so that i can take food back...(I'm a flight attendant) don't judge me with my lunchbox in a hotel situation.  Order as much food as you can but make sure u try those dry ribs...aammmaazing...
author: Ashley J.

description: Great good at fair prices! I got the chicken with peanuts and loved it! Would highly recommend coming here
author: Raymond B.

description: The food in Little Szechuan is soooooo delicious! Highly recommend!! Fish Fillet Boiled w/Flaming Chill Oil, Braised String Bean and Hot & Sour Bean Jello in Soup are so good!
author: Eavan Z.

description: This place is absolutely amazing! I was feeling very underwhelming by the Szechuan style Chinese places that I tried until I was introduced to Little Szechuan, and I will no longer go anywhere else! Very authentic Szechuan style! If you are looking for the real Chinese style spicy food, you can't miss this wonderful place! The food are tasty, fresh, and great service! They have ton of the food choices! Again, if you like spicy food, this is the right place for you! YOU MUST GO!
author: Yuan J.

description:
You'd wonder why so much hate? Some people just can't handle the real deal.!!
This is an Authentic spicy Sichuan food restaurant with very limited wait time. From sitting down to get our first dish is within 5-10 mins. We went there around 5:30 to avoid the line. Their special baked fish dish is dream come true.
Seating  is relatively spacious, everyone is very happy in the restaurant. The windows are small, the air flow is not quite the quality of the food, but the taste of the fresh ingredients made up for that. 
I highly recommend to get the baked fresh fish dish.
author: Effi W.

description: There were 6 of us. We tried several dishes. Not very authentic. If you like American style Chinese food, then this mi guy be good enough. Otherwise you are better off with Z&Y or Spicy King in Chinatown.
author: Cindy W.

description: Its my first time to try their whole fish. Surprising me that is also taste so good, same as the taste when I tried in China. Also recommendation for house combo chowmein! Yum yum!!!!!!!I definitely will come back.
author: Biyi P.

description: When I get in the city , hotel guy recommend this restaurant, then I come here, feel really nice restaurants. Good service, good price and good food.  I order The chef special spicy whole fish is authentic. Very very  good taste , amazing place,Highly recommend!!!
author: Betty L.

description: Great food! Everything we had was excellent. Came to SanFran from Chicago for great food and this place didn't disappoint. Crab Rangoon, egg rolls, dumplings,fried rice and beef and broccoli was order and we'd get it all again.
author: Kim H.

description: Worst Chinese food ever! The food was really bland. The steamed rice has more flavor! And the taro drink? You even skimped on the milk. Never again.
author: Aileen C.

description:
This place is incredible. Shanghai steamed dumplings,Spicy Wontons,Kung Pao chicken, braised stting bean,Beef boiled with flaming chili oil are pretty good. 

A lot of different items I'd like to try the next time, so we will be back.
author: Xiaolong C.

description: Had a problem but manager took care of me in the end - will give another chance next time I'm in town - thank you!!
author: Adam L.

description: LOVED this place. Feeling lazy after a day of walking in the Wharf, we decided to come home and order in. Found this place on Postmates, and it didn't let us down. Had the beef chow mein, general tso chicken, crab rangoon, and egg rolls. The food arrived rather quickly, and everything looked and tasted great. Noodles were about on par with most places, but the beef was very flavorful and fresh. Same for the chicken. Will definitely hit this place up again on my next visit to SF.
author: Andre P.

description:
Delicious spicy food and I usually get the spicy fish and dumplings swimming in chili oil. 

The staff is really switched on and happy to add vegetables to my spicy fish, which isn't always the case in Chinese restaurants. 

Nice aesthetic inside, booths for comfortable dining with a few people and nice large tables for dining with bigger groups.
author: A H.

description:
Delicious Sichuan a little further out of the rush that is Chinatown. The food is comparable and the service is better than what you can expect at most Chinese restaurants. The service staff serve the food faaast but with a GIANT smile on their faces. 

The food can be pretty spicy, beware.
author: Prasenjit M.

description: Not that spicy and tasty, but it is still a good try in SF downtown. I ordered chili oil fish hot pot by recommendation, it is served with veggies and soup. It's good to combine it with some appetizer like sour & spicy glass noodles and rice,  definitely will warm you up for those freezing days. I will give four stars, since there are several outstanding Sichuan and Hunan restaurants nearby my place I can choose.
author: Alicia L.

description: I ordered through Yelp delivery (Eat 24) and did not get my food for over 2 hours. I didn't eat the food so I've been trying to get a refund from either Yelp or Eat24 or the restaurant but haven't heard from either.
author: Christina F.

description: Really awful Chinese food - shameful for San Francisco. Try Elaine's kitchen or anywhere else .5/10 Actually ended up throwing out the general tso's chicken and Tofo we ordered because it was that bad.
author: Ryan C.

description: Sigh... another premium price D grade Chinese restaurant. All my dishes were assembled with the lowest grade ingredients and least amount of care. No shortage on grease however... They get two stars due to the lack of post meal gastric distress.
author: Tom H.

description:
My usual spot for milk tea is cash only and I didn't have any on me. Their window had a huge sign of their drinks so I decided to give it a try. I ordered a Thai iced tea. The lady went to counter in the back and I followed her over. She pulled out a jug of pre made tea and then pulled out a bottle of what I thought was condensed milk... Poured some in and asked me to try it to see if it was sweet enough. I did. It wasn't, so I gave it back and asked for it to be a bit sweeter. Then she pulls out a jar of SUGAR and puts a full spoon of it in my cup. She did it before I could stop her. I'm pretty sure the jar was really watered down condensed milk because it wasn't sweet at all. I would definitely not come here for the drinks. You simply do not use sugar for Thai iced tea. Too bad I had already paid the $4.33 for the drink and went on tasting the sugar in my mouth.

Update for the owner: I have the right business. I was there Tuesday afternoon.
author: Shabnam S.

description: Really disappointing. Delivery didn't take too long, but the food was a fried gloppy mess and lacking in flavor. It also didn't keep well in the fridge.
author: Dave R.

description: Very mediocre food. We waiting 45-60 minutes for our food. It seems they prioritize their delivery orders. The food was bland and felt like it was cooked in a flash/rush. I wouldn't go here to eat for dinner or lunch. Pass. Customer service was no where to be found.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
13 COURSE MEAL

Who knew resting on the boarder of Chinatown and Little Italy, between several dirty Gentlemen's Clubs and a couple Adult Video shops would be a great little Chinese restaurant serving a 13 course meal. Only my friend would find this space for her wedding reception celebration. 

6pm sharp the doors opened leading us down several steps to a dark but cute downstairs banquet. I would have NEVER known about this place. It's separated from the restaurant upstairs. The space is an open canvas - my friend laid out the logistics fairly well. There was a TV, music, no bar but area we managed to turn into a bar. Six large round tables fitting 10 people each and nearly a server for each table with a 13 course meal. I kid you not! It was very good I barely managed after the 6th item. All were delicious (excluding the duck - I don't eat duck). Something about Szechuan cooking is pretty amazing. All this food for each table and each table had lots of leftovers. Steal deal in my books.

Chicken Lettuce wrap 
Spicy Beef and Vegetable dumpling 
Seafood with Tofu Eggdrop Soup
Mongolian Beef 
Roast Duck 
Honey Walnut Prawns
Lobster 
Crab 
Fish 
Pea Sprouts with Garlic
Seafood Fried Rice
Stir fry Eggplant 
Noodles

I hope my pictures will do justice - though I'm missing one. Excuse the pictures with portions missing, it was tough to keep plates intact before dismantling. 

The space does need AC. They leave the door open and a fan is running but when everybody is drunk off of endless bottles of wine, AC would have been nice.  The service was great, but annoying when they kept ducking and serving while trying to record the groom and bride speech (can't they just go around)?!?! And no water for the longest time. Everybody has to keep asking for water, halfway through the night they managed to bring pitches of water for each table. But the staff was very accommodating to many other needs. 

Will I be back? Yes indeed!!!!

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description: Came here on a Friday because every thing along Kearny was full by 12:20 pm and this was basically the only Asian place left at the end of our walk. We were the only table until a small group came off a tour bus. Then two other two person tables eventually came in. I liked the darkness of the furniture and the ambiance because it didn't feel like your typical red and gold Chinese place. It was a little more upscale with a bar and wine bottles lined up and even the restrooms are fancier than most (left over from the previous place I'm sure). However, the service was not very attentive until the actual server arrived about 45 min later and the food was less than average but came out really fast. We started off with the Triple Dumplings. They miscounted the dumplings as we were missing one. They were ok tasting. I could taste the flavor of the Mushroom one though I didn't get much flavor from the other two. The server didn't say what they were when he set them down. The Spicy Green Beans were crunchy and tasty and not too oily. I didn't care too much for their Pork Noodle Soup or Xiao Long Bao because it was all quite bland. Everything was edible but I don't think I'll be back with so many better choices around. I was hoping that the food would be tastier but the flavors were lacking.
author: Jen L.

description: Worst hot and sour soup ever! They use a really weird smelly black vinegar that just ruins the taste of the soup. Awful, would not recommend!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
Really slow delivery. Messed up my order a few times.

But damn is that salt and pepper squid so delicious.

I will continue to eat that deep fried squid for a long time.

The food is really good. Please note that my all my orders have been made online and for delivery so I can only really judge delivery times and food tastiness.

Food tastiness is a+

Delivery is hit or miss.

Tea and Bobas get an f- sadly.

Salt and pepper squid is awesome.
author: Niana D.

description: Not a fan.  The chicken meat was crunchy and scary. I couldn't eat it.  The waiter tried to convince me it was fried first, but even fried chicken is tender.
author: David B.

description:
I was craving Chinese food and decided to order Little Szechuan on Caviar food app since they were offering free delivery from this place. Unfortunately, it was a let down. I ordered the crab wontons and general tso chicken. One good thing was that they made my food very fast. But it just tasted okay. It's a bummer because their portion sizes are great! But I didn't want to eat a lot of the food, it just wasn't that good. I feel bad for saying this, but Panda Express is better.

The crab wontons were a little soggy, and the sweet & sour sauce came in little cheap packets. It wasn't very impressive. The general tso chicken was pretty bland and I was hoping it would be spicy. The sauce was very sticky and just felt like a giant blob of gel. I also ordered a side of white rice and they only filled the rice container about halfway full. Sadly, I don't have any desire to order from this place again.
author: Chisholm T.

description:
First time getting Little Szechuan since last summer....but so glad I did. Ordered from EAT24, and got our food within an hour. And...I got a heads-up that they were running late via text. No biggie, it was Friday during rush hour in the city. 

We ordered MuShu Chicken - YES
Spicy Green Beans - YES YES
Pork Fried Rice - PRETTY GOOD

None of it was greasy, and no belly ache afterwards.
author: Amy O.

description:
My preferred Chinese restaurant in the area was closed, so I ventured to Little Szechuan instead. Plus I generally love Szechuan food so why not? I was craving Mapo Tofu so I ordered that and steamed rice as take-out. The bill came to $13, and I realized that the serving size was meant to be shared family style. So much food... oh well.

There were only two other people dining in the restaurant, but the food took forever to prepare. The staff members working there were nice and apologized that it took so long, but I'll just attribute the long wait to the freshness of the food. The Mapo Tofu itself was decent. The texture was thick and the flavor was sufficiently spicy. Definitely different than Mapo Tofu I've had anywhere else.

Although I still prefer another Chinese restaurant nearby, I'm glad I got to try somewhere new!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I was only in San Francisco for a few days so I decided to get some delicious authentic San Francisco food while I was in town with some friends.  
I thought from the reviews that this was going to be a nice, casual dinner experience.  I also expected some nice Szechuan style just like back on the East Coast.

First, we were greeted by a well-decored place in the front.  Then as we sat down and were guided to our seats, the waiter proceeded to give us our water glasses.  It wasn't until 15 minutes later that we realized they didn't give tea.  Every single sit down chinese place I've been to gives tea.

The kitchen also needs some work.  Even though they advertise as Szechuan, nothing was spicy.  I think there's lots of great cuisine to experience San Francisco but this place was below average on my scale.
author: Sunny L.

description:
Ordered from Caviar:
 - Chicken Salad $10.23
- Seafood with Tofu Soup $14.23

Both were decently sized, but I was disappointed to see the chicken salad came with fried popcorn-sized chicken. I was hoping for grilled chicken. Seems like everything here is fried or swimming in oil. Otherwise the salad was ok. It had just basic toppings: iceberg lettuce, a few large tomato slices, a little corn.

The seafood & tofu soup had potential--it was packed with fried tofu and white fish, along with a few shrimp, calamari and octopus pieces. I also saw some bok choi, a few carrot slices, and zucchini. However, it came in what looked like a thick, white sludge. Not appetizing.

However, after a minute of washing it through the strainer, the "soup" was much more palatable.
author: A -.

description: Really good Szechuan food in SF. Fair price and good share. Boiling beef is really good, the pan cake is yummy as well. And sometimes you could find Lady M served here!
author: Simin G.

description: We love szechuan food and thus had high expectations from this place. Unfortunately it was not very good. We have had some amazing szechuan and this didn't stand to that level. We had asked for spicy so instead of adding chili they just added more szechuan peppers (which is not chili). Also They didn't cook the szechuan pepper in oil and added it whole so everything just become too numbing. There was no flavor just numbing effect and was not able to eat anything without biting into the szechuan peppers. This was surely szechuan food not done right.
author: Garima C.

description: I'm going to re-confirm my bullish bet on Little Szech!  Little Szech continues to be my favorite Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.  Their lunch specials are extremely generous so I never have to worry about going hungry.  They make the food exactly the way I want it and are always happy to do so.  Plus, the health score has been taken up to 98 which is like the equivalent of scoring a 150 for Chinese restaurants.  Really, nothing to complain about.  I'd really recommend it if you want great Chinese food.
author: Patrick L.

description: Original Chinese food, nice environment. Even though the price is a little bit higher than the low end Chinese restaurant around the area, it is definitely worth the money! :)
author: Mike W.

description:
Why so much hate? 
This place is fabulous. The environment is cozy and comfortable. The staff are very friendly and helpful. My girlfriend wanted to try the pork intestine hot pot; the waitress was concerned with her choice and tried her best to explain what she is getting herself into lol gf ended up loving the dish. We also ordered the duck with white rice on the side and the stir fried green beans. The flavour, presentation and texture was all 10/10. If you want to try some tasty Chinese dishes, this is a great place to hit.
We left nothing behind, even though the hot pot was quite spicy for our taste.
author: Yanko Z.

description: Braised chicken dish is awesome. Order through Caviar to North Beach was quick and the delivery is well packed. Awesome flavor, thanks to the Szechuan pepper! Will order again soon.
author: Braden F.

description: The BBQ fish is good, very spicy with I like. Also it has lot of veggie. Service is attentive. Over all can't complain.
author: Qing L.

description:
There seems to be a lot of conflicting views on Yelp about this place-either you love it or you hate it. I happened to love it, and I think for regular Chinese food it's the best I've ever had. 

I got the fried rice and sesame chicken and both were excellent. Not too salty but lots of flavor and didn't taste like a reheated frozen meal (my experience with many Chinese restaurants). The service was very nice and extremely fast. I got my food within minutes of ordering. 

Added bonus: very nice check in deal!
author: Shelby B.

description: Love this place! If you're looking to satisfy a spicy hotpot craving, then THIS IS THE PLACE! I was surprised by the level of spicy as well as the numbness! For those who are looking for both hotpot and a good variety THIS IS THE PLACE! 120% RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!!! :)
author: Sherry Y.

description: Amazing food and service. I ordered spicy crispy chicken for delivery and the delivery guy Tyler was friendly and patient. Recommend this place to anyone who likes excellent Chinese food.
author: Chiang H.

description:
Skip if you can, there are better places in Chinatown.

Went here a few days ago because f high ratings on Yelp. Located in the heart of Broadway, this place is flanked by strip clubs. Who wouldn't want Chinese food right after a striptease, right? Or may be you prefer it before? 

Anyway, ordered spicy shuimai for appetizers, which came at the end. When we asked the surver to cancel it, she told us that was not possible. The three of us had fun trying to find the chicken pieces among the chillies. The red chillies were delicious though. Mongolian beef was decent and so was the mixed veggies. The shuimai, not so much. Not sure whether it was because we had to treat it as a desert.

Given the food was nothing exceptional, I will explore other places next time I am in Chinatown. Dim sum, anyone?
author: Aashish J.

description: The atmosphere of this Sichuan restaurant on Broadway street is pretty nice.  The restaurant  is run by Cantonese.   To me the flavor of the Sichuan dishes taste more like a fusion of northern and Sichuan style.  The servers are somewhat attentive unlike some of the other Chinese restaurant where the wait staff rather chit-chatt with each other instead of attending to the customers.
author: Henry L.

description: The person delivering my order demanded a tip so gave him one but he didn't deserve on. Food wasn't good at all !
author: Jonathan G.

description: The food is amazing and the service is top class . A must stop for amazing cuisine for any one anytime .the service is prompt and efficient. Eat in or order to go .it's worth every dollar you'll spend . Just all round one of the best Chinese Oriental food there is if you happen to be in San Francisco . Highly recommend
author: Avi P.

description:
I came here around 9pm on a Friday evening. The place is located within little Italy, next to many other restaurants and night life. We were hungry and didn't crave Italian, so found this place and went in without a wait.
The service wasn't fantastic, as we got seated without napkins and plates like the other tables did. We didn't get much attention so we took some off of another table. 
We ordered the spicy beef (水煮牛肉). It did have the Sichuan numbing peppers unlike many other places I've ordered this dish from. It was definitely spicy and exhilarating to my taste buds. 
Two bowls of rice were charged extra.
The appetizer was beef flank and tendons (in Chinese it's called 夫妻肺片). It didn't taste as spicy as other places I've had it, not sure if I liked it or didn't; it was just DIFFERENT, like a nutty flavor. The portion was decent for the price.
With just two dishes and rice, it fed the two of us AND we had the leftovers taken to go, which was good for breakfast the next day.
Overall, the service isn't great, just like most Chinese places that offer good food for reasonable prices. However, the decor and atmosphere was fine and not gaudy or dirty. Decent crowd for a late night dinner. I'd come again for another night if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Alice S.

description:
This was the first time that I've ever eaten Chinese take-out. Yes you read that correctly...I've had my fair share of Chinese food in my day (both good and bad) but, my family never gets it as take-out. So I was a little skeptical about how well Chinese food tastes when its been delivered.

Overall, I was pleasantly surprised with Little Szechuan. We ordered a variety of items (they have literally like a hundred menu items to choose from) and the portion sizes were pretty big. I would highly recommend ordering the spicy green beans, mongolian beef, and potstickers.

I was really disappointed with the shanghai soup dumplings. Let's be honest folks, this is just one dish that is not good unless it is hot and fresh. I also don't recommend buying the mushu pork because it was very dry and lacked flavor.

I'd definitely order take-out from Little Szechuan again, and I would recommend it as long as you are careful about what you order! Check out the lunch specials for a great deal!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Quaint little sichuan restaurant

Never would have expected a place like this in c-town! The place looks completely new, clean, equipped with several flat screen TVs, and quiet. Essentially everything about this place is the opposite of what you'd see at other c-town restaurants!

Except the food. The food is spicy, numbing, and definitely up to par. Even by c-town standards, the food quality of this place exceeds expectations!

For some reason they also have a giant bubble tea menu. Hmph. I usually don't see that in sichuan places.

A good place to go for authentic sichuan spiciness
author: Henry L.

description: IMO, the best chinese food in SF. The original taste from Sichuan. Try it if you like spicy food. The environment are nice and clean. Servers are nice and helpful.
author: Keming Z.

description: We came in on a Saturday night, my girlfriend was carving for grill whole fish, so then we found this place on yelp, we were amazed how good it is, it tasted really good, very flavorful. The noodle was decent, the service was also pretty intense, I would definitely come back for the fish again. :)
author: Jalen H.

description: Love the style of the restaurant, when i walked in it felt like I'm back at home, the food is on point, I loved the braised crispy chicken with red chilly,  it taste just like the one I ate before in szechuan, super authentic!! I would give a 5 star to this restaurant just because of the customer service, the owner is super friendly and would often check on me to see if I need anything,  other than the delicious food, I am surprised that they also server high quality BOBA TEA drinks!!
author: John Y.

description: This was a pick up order. I am a vegetarian and ordered a bunch of stuff. The staff was courteous and friendly. The vegetarian pot stickers were doughy and flavorless. The green onion pancakes and fried rice were tasteless where as the ma po tofu had an interesting pinkish color. I am not sure what was added to it. Overall not a good choice for vegetarians especially those looking for spicy Chinese food. My search for good Szechuan food continues.
author: Sonica T.

description:
The staff is very friendly, but some lack the English language. However, when a question is asked, someone does come quickly to assist. 

A big plus. This restaurant is at the outskirts of Chinatown, but yet the restaurant has a good atmosphere, and it is clean. 

The food is average, nothing that stands out really (cashew chicken, pork & vegetable dumplings). 

What I did enjoy was the spicy shui mai.  It was different and good.
author: C W.

description: This is definitely one of the best Sichuan restaurants in SF.  We ordered spi chili Bf chill which is the most traditional dishes. Sososososo good! People who like hot food must go to this one! Believe me!
author: Kiki C.

description:
My family and I were pleasantly surprised.  We went early to avoid the Christmas Eve crowd.  We were seated right away and the food came out quickly and presented nicely.  I wasn't too fond of the main dish, but it was a taste preference, the food had good quality, but it wasn't my preference.  The appitzers were really good, except for the free sticky rice item that is free coupon on Yelp.  Again it was a preference and had nothing to do with the quality of the dish. 

We will certainly go back when visiting San Francisco.
author: Michelle B.

description: This is only one of my favorite restaurant in Chinatown. Trust me this is the only place can make the real Sichuan food in Chinatown. The serve is awesome too. Nice place and really clean environment.
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
Brand new szechuan place that just opened late jan 2014.

They are on broadway close to several of the strip clubs. Not sure how this will affect their traffic.

The staff are very friendly.

They use printed labels on their takeout containers so you know what you ordered - wow this is a first for me.

Tan Tan noodles were good.

Spicy wontons were a little doughy

Fish in chili oil was very spicy but good

Will be back to try more.
author: David T.

description: There is no better place. The food, atmosphere, and service is simply excellent! Great vegan options!
author: Anthony K.

description:
I would rate the food here four stars, but unfortunately the slow service knocks off a star. My friend and I came in for dinner on a Sunday night, when the place was only about half full, and it took over an hour before we actually got any of our food. On top of that, they completely forgot one of our dishes. 

The food itself is actually pretty good. My and I ordered the bean jelly, cucumber salad, and spicy crispy chicken. The bean jelly was just the right amount of spicy oiliness goodness and the chicken was wonderfully crispy. The cucumber salad was also nice and refreshing and very light. 

Overall, I would recommend the food at Little Szechuan, but maybe get take out or delivery next time.
author: Jean J.

description: Spicy items had the perfect level of heat and salt for Szechuan IMHO. Generous portions, and complimentary rice
author: Aaron P.

description:
Almost 4 stars for food, no more than 3 for service. Server was polite and friendly, but order got mixed up, affecting the food. We ordered an appetizer, 2 dishes and rice. One of the dishes, salt & pepper fish fillets, came quickly followed by the appetizer. When the server came by to check we asked about the other dish and rice. "Oh, I'll get them!" Szechwan beef and rice appeared quickly, to the detriment of the beef. 
 
Salt & pepper fish was very good, crisp breading and vert hot. A little salty to my taste
Five spice beef roll was good, a little messy to eat.
Szechwan beef was tasty but the meat was too chewy. Probably because of the rush to serve. 
 
I'll be back, there are many things of interest on the menu.
author: Peter R.

description: Had the Braised chicken with chili peppers and had them make it very spicy.  Excellent!
author: JazTrance ..

description: It was my first time going to this restaurant. I was very satisfied with the service and the delicious food. I would highly recommend this place if you love spicy food!!!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Since this was a new Sichuan place in Chinatown, I felt that I should come check it out and see if it really was worth the recent praises. Being that this place used to be a night club, the decor and setup were definitely very different from a typical Chinese place. The inside is still very dark; I realize they are trying for a more classy feel, but it feels very out of place with the type of food served. Even if it's supposed to high-class Chinese food, which I don't think it really is. The booths were just chairs instead of actual booth cushions, the water glasses seemed more appropriate for mixed drinks, the paint job looked half-finished, the "Chinese" decorations were way overdone, and they just kept playing "Say Something" on repeat. Very strange and very different experience.

Food was also somewhat underwhelming, especially for the prices. I was hoping for the lunch menu, which I saw online, but we came here at noon on a Friday and didn't get one. Much of the menu seemed to be regular Americanized Chinese food. We ended up ordering one appetizer, the Five Spices Beef Roll, was not so much Five Spices as it was lukewarm instead of hot, soft instead of crispy, and weirdly sweet inside instead of flavorful. And this came out 10 minutes after our main entree too, which was fairly confusing. 

The fish fillet boiled in chili broth (shuizhu yu) was the order I was most looking forward to. Appearance-wise it was not bad and seemed quite large, with an abundance of chili peppers. After tasting it though, I felt largely disappointed. Despite all the chili, it was not nearly spicy enough, and more importantly it was not mouth-numbing (ma) enough. The broth itself was mostly fish and chili, and very devoid of vegetables, of which it should have a decent amount. 

While waiting for our food, we were wondering if our water would be refilled, but eventually we had to call a waiter over. At which point, they just brought the entire water bottle and placed it on our table. Why not just do that to begin with?

I acknowledge that Sichuanese food is rare otherwise in SF. Also because they are new, so I am hoping they will improve as time goes on. But I will give a while before I go back there, if ever.
author: Tony D.

description: This place is really bad. My girlfriend and I stopped in last night around 845 and we were hoping for some genuine sichuan Mala flavor. Not only was there zero numbing and barely any spiciness, I could tell they only were offering dishes like that because it's been trendy lately but this place is totally Americanised. We are from LA and regularly go out to San Gabriel Valley for authentic sichuan flavors and this was so far away from that that it was a huge disappointment.
author: Noah I.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with the food at Little Szechuan. Didn't know what to expect with its location on Broadway.

- Dong Po Marinated pork was excellent.
- Braised Crispy Chicken with Jalapeños was great. Very juicy, great flavor, and good heat.
- Tan Tan Noodle also great. Delicious with heat. 
- Beef Chow Fun was alright, but my daughter loved it.
- Cumin Beef was disappointing. The beef was very dry...way overlooked...and the flavor was a bit off.

Service was very good.
Will definitely be back.
author: Zoran L.

description:
Pretty good food. Not amazing, but good.

Service is ... Chinese. Which means it's as good as true French service but with the extra upsell. The waitress, whom I think may be the co-owner, kept trying to push things onto us. Especially the highest priced items. She also would keep things on the list of things that we ordered, even if I asked for another entree to replace the original one. If it were common to haggle for food prices I'm sure she would have tried. She also ignored us once we were done ordering - we ended up paying at the register.

- Spicy wontons: 2/5. Not very spicy and bland. Doughy. Don't recommend.
- Schezuan tofu: 4/5. I really liked this dish and am glad we didn't get the mapo tofu. It's fried and put on a sizzling platter, with zucchinis, peppers, and onions with sauce over it.
- Chicken with chilis: 4/5. Beautiful dish, but not too much in the way of chicken. Lots of beautiful peppers strewn around and the dish is very pretty. 

Overall, very glad I didn't spend the extra money + tip to order from here on trycaviar.
author: Sylvia L.

description: Great food, amazing customer services. I love their chief special whole fish, it was delicious. Guys, this is the one you can not miss.
author: anna l.

description: Oh man was this not good. I ordered the chili dumplings, shanghai dumplings, and braised crispy beef. The chili dumplings needed salt and the sauce was very, very oily. The shanghai dumplings had little flavor and the dipping sauce tasted like straight vinegar. However, the worst was the beef; it was so salty that my mouth burned. I couldn't finish anything any my stomach is currently in knots. Never again.
author: Stephanie S.

description: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in the city. It is affordable, great service, and the food is great. I am a veggie and am sooo happy for all the veg options! Vegetarian dim sum can be hard to find the city and Little Szechuan nails it. My friend ordered the whole fish and raved about it. I've also ordered takeout here a bunch of times and they are so quick and nice to me. I really appreciate the care to customer service and excellent food at affordable prices. Thank you LS!!!
author: Jane R.

description:
This place was simply amazing and the service was the best! I ordered delivery and they were here within 20 minutes with fresh hot food.
I ordered the braised crispy chicken with red chili oil, brown rice & crab rangoons with the Hong Kong milk tea. Everything was perfection! I will make this a stop every trip that I take to San Fran in the future!
author: J L.

description:
Coming in here on a Sunday night was interesting as this place was maybe half full.  I had made a reservation for my party of 8, but it ended up not being needed (if you have a large party, you should probably always call ahead anyway, however).  Upon arrival and throughout the night, the staff was very attentive, friendly, and overall doing a good job.  We noticed during the dinner some people came in from a tour and gave the staff some attitude - the situation didn't escalate and was dealt with quickly, so good job done there.  It's nice anywhere when a restaurant isn't busy - you'll get your food quickly and better follow-up service (which we did).  The interior is nice and there are some TVs for sports at the bar - visible to the whole restaurant.  There's also a downstairs area that I didn't get to see, I'm assuming for larger parties or when the restaurant fills up.

We tried to get a big sampling of the menu, and most of the food was very good:

A5 Pot Stickers - kind of difficult to screw this one up.  They didn't have enough sear for my taste, but overall wasn't bad.

A15 Salt and Pepper Calamari - good seasoning, well cooked, good portion size (would've liked more but it is an appetizer).
B5 Sliced Pork with Spicy Garlic Sauce - one of the table favorites - the pork was cooked perfectly and still moist, while the sauce was a great focal point.  Enough for all 8 people to try a few bites, and a very strong flavor.  Would recommend, especially if you like garlic.

F17 Pork Intestine Boiled with Flaming Chili Oil - the #1 dish at the table.  I personally love intestines, and have had it in most Asian countries.  It was a difficult sell to my semi-adventurous group, especially because it also looked like it was at spice level 10.  The intestine was so juicy and was just popping with flavor - overcooked intestine can turn rubbery/chewy real fast, and this was both chewy and tender at the same time.  The broth was great as well.  A must try, especially if you've never had intestine before.

J2 Braised Crispy Chicken with Red Chili Oil - chicken was juicy and flavorful, and with a beautiful presentation.  Spice level was a bit lower than I expected and the chicken could have been crispier.

K2 Ma Po Tofu - I had a problem with this one, as I've had different Ma Po Tofus around the world including in Chengdu.  The spice level was just not even close to what I would expect - this dish should be numbing your mouth, and I was barely feeling the heat.  The sauce was a bit thin as well, and the tofu itself could have been cooked a bit longer.  I had a chat with the manager afterwards about it and cleared this up - it was probably partially my fault for not specifying the spice level I wanted (although I was never asked).  I've also had ground meat included in this dish almost every other time I've had it, and this was a vegetarian version of it - so that was just my preference.  I would expect a Szechuan restaurant to execute this dish perfectly, and next time I go back I'll ask for the real deal - I'll update my review accordingly.

K11 Pea Sprouts with Garlic - expertly cooked, with a ton of flavor and a crispiness that is required for Chinese vegetables.  Would order again.

R4 Orange Beef - cloying flavor, reminded me a little bit of Chinese fast food.  I didn't choose this one, I probably wouldn't again.  Portion was a bit small.

R13 Cumin Lamb - cooked well, a bit on the tough side, but good flavor here too - veggies were a mix of soft and crispy.  Enough for everyone to try a little bit.

Overall I enjoyed the dinner and everyone else did too.  Good food, good service, and I met the manager who spoke to me about my food concerns listed above.  Not as good as what you'd find in Chengdu, but a good option if you're in the North Beach area.  I'll come back to get the real Mapo Tofu experience in the future.  I'll probably try a few other Szechuan places first to get a comparison.
author: Ben K.

description: Want good spicy and authentic Si Chuan dishes? Look no further, here is where to ALL OF THAT! Being from, SF I was floored to find such a place! Bring your friends and fam here! :)
author: Tony W.

description: I was so excited to see beef chow fun on the menu when I got here.  It's a menu item I first had at a Chinese restaurant in Baltimore that I never find on other restaurant menus. So I was sorely disappointed in this one.  It was so regular in taste.  The beef was very tender however but unless I have idolized the memory of the beef chow fun years ago, this one was not up to snuff.  Order was takeout, quick and so no complaints there.
author: Dawn B.

description:
If you like spicy, go this !
I order fish fillets with chili oil, that is amazing, taste!
Other dish is string beans, I'm ask for less spicy, that come is good! This place in china town  is very clear, you know china town no restaurant clear ! I love here in my trip ! I will come back again ! Highly recommend!
author: Hua D.

description: The food is ok but I don't think it represents the real Sichuan spicy food. It's more like American Chinese food but add some spices. I was actually very disappointed.
author: Ash T.

description: Service was excellent and the food was phenomenal!!! I enjoyed their spicy food a lot, will definitely be coming back !!!
author: Leo T.

description: I don't usually get crab rangoon but my friend wanted to split it so we tried it. It ended up making both of our stomachs upset for the rest of the day. There was essentially no crab meat in the rangoon, the outer shell was soggy and it was all cream cheese on the inside....really the worst case scenario for a Rangoon. The only reason I'm giving 2 stars is because the szechuan cold noodles we're okay.
author: Nate P.

description: First time go to this restaurant; the atmosphere is nice with friendly staffs. They're very welcoming. I didn't order the spicy food today. Next time I definitely gonna try the spicy whole fish entree due to I saw others comment said it's tasty :)
author: Joeceline Z.

description: No food 2 hours after ordering, called and told driver left five minutes ago...still No food and then delivered to the wrong address.  Restaurant then calls me asking about my order and to tell me driver dropped it off at my apartment.  They then had the driver call me swearing he dropped it off and said he's coming back because he knows he dropped it off.  Me hungry and two hours later still no food, wait outside out of spite to prove I did not get food and the driver shows up and says oh wrong address. He runs to the next building as to retrieve the food and I say no, I want my money back...As if he were going to give me food he delivered to someone else already.
author: Chris S.

description:
Very busy restaurant-we went at 1:00pm and still waited about 15 minutes for a table for three.Highly recommend calling ahead to make a reservation!                   We had the spicy whole fish (烤鱼） ，hot & sour bean jelly(酸辣粉），salt & pepper tofu(椒盐豆腐)，hot&sour soup(酸辣汤)，A vege(蒜蓉A菜)！All very well done ,and the wantons were our favorite.
If you plan to eat there do allow plenty of time for serving.
author: Yuhang W.

description: Very nice place. Not extremely authentic chinese food restaurant. But still pretty delicious
author: Renju L.

description: Sesame chicken is delicious!!! Delivered in 25 mins, food wasn't as warm as I preferred it to be but honestly one of the best sesame chicken I've tasted in a while. I definitely will order again from this establishment. The garlic and eggplants were cooked with bell peppers in which I wish I knew before ordering because I don't like peppers but overall good order. In addition, tried the crispy chicken with chilli peppers, I wouldn't order that again because it wasn't crispy like advertised. For what it is, its good food.
author: Noor S.

description:
10 stars from the LA native who is used to Panda Express on every corner. It's been over a year since I last visited here (not by choice) but I remember it like it was yesterday. Honestly you can't find good Szechuan in LA and this blew away anything you could scrounge up in our Chinatown. This was my first time in The City so being able to experience their Chinatown and hopefully what I perceived to be "authentic" was a great immersion in a new culture. It was like being transplanted to a whole new part of the world. Anyway, we walked in and they were not busy at all, and I really liked the overall ambiance, dark furniture red accents, friendly staff. 
We sat down and we're given these little spicy nuts to nibble on while we looked at the menu and they were so tasty. First I ordered the passionfruit smoothie to drink. It was my first time trying passion fruit and this was the place where I fell in love with it. It had a jumbo straw which I though was fun. I don't remember what my then boyfriend got to drink but honestly it was forgettable compared to my passionfruit delight. Then we started ordering food. I stuck to what I knew which was orange chicken and my bf got beef and broccoli. For sides we got fried rice of course and veggie chow mein. We also got egg rolls and I think a couple other things which I can't quite recall but I can tell you everything I put in my mouth I liked. The orange chicken had this delicate, light breading but still crispy--it was like nothing I've ever tasted and I'm not exaggerating. I must say, the sauce was of the chaiiin good and I sometimes wish to make that 6 hour drive just to go up there for lunch. The chow mein noodles were so good the veggies were cooked but still had a crunch and the sauce was delicious. I even liked my mans beef and broccoli and I usually am not a fan. The egg rolls also had a light crispy exterior and I remember loving every bite I took. Maybe I don't know good Chinese, many my taste buds know what they are talking about, either way this is by far my favorite Chinese spot and I can't wait to go back.
author: Jade W.

description:
This place is a rip-off.  I placed 3 lunch orders for pick up...pawns chow mein... menu price $8.98...charged $9.98.  Chicken chow mein...menu price $6.98...charged  $7.98. The extra $1.00 is because I didn't tell her I wanted the lunch special and they gave me dinner portion (really ). It's 12:30 in the afternoon, why would I order from the dinner menu. 

 Common sense people. ..

The worst is my co-worker order. She ordered salt and pepper fish, but want fried rice instead of steam.  She was charged of $8.98 for the fish and additional $3.98 for the fried rice.  Seriously!  

Advice : please tell the customer about the price difference at the time of an order.

As to the food, my prawns chow mein was too oily and soggy.  My co-worker Salt and pepper fish was too salty. 

We are never going back there.  They have no common sense when comes to customer services.
author: Pamela F.

description: Their delivery is fast and steaming hot. Exactly what needed when I was sick in bed for a week. My regular order consists of Westlake Beef Soup, Chicken with Chilis, Braised String Beans, and Beef with Broccoli. Their lunch special is an amazing deal. For those lazy weeks, I just order a bunch of these for the upcoming days and eat them for dinner :) secret's out!
author: Fiona Y.

description:
I was in San Francisco for a seminar that gave us a short meal window.  I had also just finished a cleanse so I was still not eating meat.  The menu accommodated my eating restrictions easily.  I had tofu with mushrooms and eggplant with garlic and brown rice.  They were tasty and satisfying as well as arriving with enough time to eat and get back.  

Other members of our group had beef egg foo young, curry chicken, moo shu pork, kung poa shrimp.  There was vegetable fried rice as well.  Everyone enjoyed there meal.
author: Doyle B.

description: 4.5.  A little pricey.  Got the bok choy and mongolian beef and both were excellent.
author: Alison D.

description:
Really mediocre. I went for lunch and ordered kung pao chicken with noodles ($2 upcharge). The soup of the day was hot and sour. Nothing about the food was memorable or even as good as the kung pao (a Szechuan dish) at the Chinese restaurant a block from me (which is actually a Hunan place).

Service was lackluster, too. When you're getting lunch as one person, you usually want to be in and out pretty rapidly. I had to flag down waitstaff to get me the check a while after I was clearly done.
author: David S.

description: Make sure u realize the won ton soup is a bucket full, 4 people can share an order. Mongolian beef was tender and delicious. Kids said sesame chicken was great and the Peking duck was good. Pancakes with duck were more like dough balls but duck was very good.
author: Brandon I.

description: Food quality really inconsistent.  Service not friendly or fast.  Stay away from general tso's never had bad tso's till nowz
author: Jason R.

description: I'm usually into spicy Szechuan food, because I used to have a Chinese gf, who turned me onto to some of the flavors, even the weird stuff I normally wouldn't order, like pigs feet anyone? But anyway, these people do the stuff I order like hot and sour soup and stir fired veggies. We always get the mu shu pork, because the little pancakes and lettuce wraps I love. They have this killer hoisin sauce and also a peanut side that I put on everything. I just wish everything wasn't so oily, but then again if it's Chinese, what am I expecting, right?
author: Mack L.

description: Very disappointing food though it was delivered promptly. The Kung Pao chicken had no flavor at all, the spring rolls and Mooshu pancakes came with sauce in a package. Fortunately their hot and sour soup was the highlight, but the vegetable dumplings were bland. We didn't need the free fortune cookies included with the order. We would have preferred tastier food accompanied by fresh sauces.
author: Lynn S.

description: No lie, i'd fight my mama over these left overs! Amazing, Amazing!!! Get here in a hurry but then don't tell anybody you're coming, because you won't want to share. LIT asf!
author: Cincere D.

description:
Its been awhile since last time i was here. The foods are still as good as alway! I couldn't eat too spicy although its a szechuan restaurant. So I requested less spicy. It came out just about right to hit the spot. Here are the item I ordered: 
- spicy dumpling, always my favorite 
- string bean, less spciy!!!
-  braid crispy chicken, looks very spicy since a lot of red pepper on the dish, but not as spicy as i though
- general tso chicken, its really real real! Its spicy sweet sour, all mixed in!!
author: Icy H.

description:
WHY WE WENT HERE:
- partied in SF the night before
- planned to spend the day in Chinatown and Yelp directed us to this place

THE LOOK (FROM THE OUTSIDE/INSIDE):
- new
- clean
- spacious
- surprised at all the TVs playing sports channels

THE MENU:
- appetizers
- lunch special
- egg foo young
- noodles/rice
- poultry
- vegetables
- hot/clay pot/sizzling platter
- beef/lamb
- pork
- seafood
- soup
- cold plates
- fresh juice
- fresh juice & vegetables juice
- fresh flavored ice tea
- flavored smoothies
- hot/ice milk tea
- drink
- dessert
- signature dish

WHAT WE ORDERED:
- fried rice
- beef chow mein
- fried chicken wings w/spicy chef sauce
- Mongolian beef
- sweet & sour pork
- Mandarin spareribs
- honey walnut prawns

THE TASTE:
- everything was WAY too salty or too saucy...
- the best thing we had was the sweet & sour pork, and I normally don't eat that

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
- excellent
author: Sarah-Lorraine L.

description:
I had a quick lunch here a couple of days ago. 
The Szechuan lamb was really mediocre and tough. The waitress also forgot the salad which was supposed to come with the lunch menu and only gave me a rebate after I had an argument with her. Not recommendable.
author: Horst M.

description:
Cute, reasonably priced restaurant just off Chinatown's main drag. Their menu has a selection of standards as well as Szechuan specialties. Their standards are fine, but if you want something spicy, go with one of the specialties! 

We got the green onion pancake, triple delight dumplings, honey walnut prawns, and lamb boiled with flaming chili oil. All were decent, or better. Three were standard. One was not.

The lamb boiled with flaming chili oil came in a HUGE dish. It was a bit more soupy than at other Szechuan restaurants, but it still had a mouth-numbing blend of peppers and peppercorns, with cilantro and bean sprouts.  The lamb (yes, it actually was lamb--I could tell by the gamey taste) was nice and tender, and soaked up the spices. This dish was massive...it could have fed two people easily, and was only $15.

The honey walnut prawns were good, although it's hard to mess those up. Adding broccoli was a nice touch. The onion pancakes were good. The dumplings were alright...I've had better at most dim sum restaurants.
